properties.Name: Baghdad
properties.Desc: Baghdad was the largest and most important city in Ottoman Iraq as well as the capital of the Waliyah of Baghdad. After the time of Wali Midhat Pasha, Baghdad's fortifications began to be dismanteld. Despite this, the 4 gateways of the old city wall remained, whcih appear often in Joseph's diaries. Baghdad boasted over 140 mosques, with the most noteable being the shrine of Skeikh Abdul Qadir Gilani, the Mosque of Maidan, the Azbak mosque, and the minaret of the Souq al-Ghazal. Connecting the city which spans the Tigris river was a 240 yard boat bridge. Baghdad was an incredibly diverse city at the time. With a population of 140,000, over a third were Jewish. The second largest ethnic group were the Arabs at around 38,500 inhabitants, but there were also Turks, Persians, Kurds, Indians, and Europeans. The Christian population was divided by sect amongst Armenian and Chaldean catholics, Syrian Catholics, Roman Catholics (also called Latins), Protestants, and Greek Orthodox communities, each with their own churches. For recreation, Baghdad was home to 12 libraries, a reading room, 28 bath houses, 7 gymnasia, and 2 hotels. Additionallly, there were over 4,000 shops, 2 bazaars, 208 khans, 235 cafes, and numours manufacturing sites. As an important administrative site, it also housed barracks, prisons, hospitals, and several governmental offices.

properties.Name: Ctesiphon
properties.Desc: Mada'in refers to the collection of ruins around 30 miles south of Baghdad. The most prominant ruins are of the Macedonian town of Seleucia and the Parthian city of Ctesiphon. In total, there were approximately 7 ancient towns built in the nearby region. Beginning in the 10th century, much of the stone ruins were deconstructed to use the building materials in Baghdad. Despite this, the population of Mada'in remained numerous for some time. By the 19th century, the area was depopulated for the most part and the most prominent ruins still standing were of the Taq Kisra, a winter palace for the Parthian kings. Across the river from the ruins of Ctesiphon was the tomb of Salman Pak (Salman the Pure), reported to be the barber for the prophet Muhammad.

properties.Name: Azizieh Village
properties.Desc: Until the 1860s, Aziziyah was the site of a police station without many other inhabitants but grew after the development of land by the Dairat as-Saniyah. The village grew to around 1,000 people until it then decreased to 200 inhabitants by 1884 as a result of the fluctuating river. Without sufficient irrigation, the townspeople rely on the nearby Shammar Toqah tribe for resources. The only major export from the village is liquorice which is run by a Jewish inhabitant given a contract from the Ottoman government.

properties.Name: Coot
properties.Desc: The population of Kut was around 4,000 consisting of Faili Kurds, Shiite Arabs, some Jews, and a handful of Christians. There was one mosque with a minaret and a synagogue. Many of the Kurds were porters while the Jews were often involved with goldsmithing and the Christians were liquorice merchants. Many of the inhabitants were involved with agriculture and cattle breeding, as well as trading agricultural products. In Kut, the Euphrates and Tigris Steam Navigation Company maintain a coal depot. The Ottoman authorities also built offices for the Dairat as-Saniyah, the Public Debt Department, and a customs house.

properties.Name: Ali Gherbi
properties.Desc: Located almost half-way between Amara and Kut, Ali al-Garbi was home to around 2,000 people in the early 20th century. The predominately Shiite population worked mianly in agriculture and trade. Products such as wheate, barley, ghee, and wool were produced for trade. The town was a depot for Kurish trade in the region and also served as the market town for the Bani Lam tribe. The town was named for a mosque dedicated to Ali, the son of Imam Musa. In town, there is a telegraph office, a customs house, and two khans.

properties.Name: Kalat Saleh
properties.Current: Qal'at Saleh; Qalat Saleh; Qal'a Salih
properties.Desc: Population of 2000, center for rice trade. Qal'at Saleh was officially called Shatrat al-Amarah by the Turkish government. It was a ll town on the left bank of the Tigris river. The town grew in the late 19th century as it became the center for the region's rice trade. The town was divided by a canal and consisted of both brick houses and mud huts. The 2,000 strong population was predominately Sunni Muslims. There were some Sabians who worked with goldsmithing and made small reed boats. The local fort for which the town is named was owned by Faisal, a chief of the Al Bu Muhammad tribe. Rice is the staple export of the town, but locals also produced corn, sesame, millet, and onions. The Dairat as-Saniyah maintained an office in the town and there were three Islamic schools and one Sabian school.

properties.Name: Amara
properties.Desc: Situtated on the left bank of the Tigirs about 130 miles above Basra. On the other side of the Tigris facing Amara are date plantations and other fruit tree orchards. The population of the town is around 10,000 consisting of 4,500 Sunnis, 3,000 Shiites, 1000 Jews, 1,000 Sabians, and 500 Christians. Most of the inhabitants are Arabs but there are also Kurds, Turkish officals, and some Persians. Many of the inhabitants are traders, artisans, and famers. The area around Amara produces a large quantity of ghee and barley which are shipped to Baghdad, Basra, Mumbai, and Europe. Amarah formed an important administrative site for the southern Iraq region as it hosted a military garrison, an office for the Dairat as-Saniyah, a customs house, a Public Debt Administration office, and a Sanitary Department. Amara grew after 1860 when the Turkish army camped in the area while fighting against the two main local Arab tribes, the Beni Lam and Al Bu Muhammad.
